Vertical Federated Learning without Revealing Intersection Membership

Jiankai Sun
jiankai.sun@bytedance.com &Xin Yang11footnotemark: 1
yangxin.yx@bytedance.com Yuanshun Yao
kevin.yao@bytedance.com

aonan.zhang@bytedance.com Weihao Gao
weihao.gao@bytedance.com &Junyuan Xie

chong.wang@bytedance.com Equal contribution. Correspondence to: {jiankai.sun, yangxin.yx, chong.wang}@bytedance.com
Abstract

Vertical Federated Learning (vFL) allows multiple parties that own different attributes (e.g. features and labels) of the same data entity (e.g. a person) to jointly train a model. To prepare the training data, vFL needs to identify the common data entities shared by all parties. It is usually achieved by Private Set Intersection (PSI) which identifies the intersection of training samples from all parties by using personal identifiable information (e.g. email) as sample IDs to align data instances. As a result, PSI would make sample IDs of the intersection visible to all parties, and therefore each party can know that the data entities shown in the intersection also appear in the other parties, i.e. intersection membership. However, in many real-world privacy-sensitive organizations, e.g. banks and hospitals, revealing membership of their data entities is prohibited. In this paper, we propose a vFL framework based on Private Set Union (PSU) that allows each party to keep sensitive membership information to itself. Instead of identifying the intersection of all training samples, our PSU protocol generates the union of samples as training instances. In addition, we propose strategies to generate synthetic features and labels to handle samples that belong to the union but not the intersection. Through extensive experiments on two real-world datasets, we show our framework can protect the privacy of the intersection membership while maintaining the model utility.

1 Introduction

With the increasing tension between data privacy and data-hungry machine learning, Federated Learning (FL)Â (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; Yuan and Ma, 2020; Ghosh etÂ al., 2020) is proposed as a privacy-enhancing technique that allows multiple parties to collaboratively train a model without completely sharing data. Depending on how data are split across parties, FL can be mainly classified into two categoriesÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019a): Horizontal Federated LearningÂ (Geiping etÂ al., 2020; Hamer etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2020) and Vertical Federated LearningÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Abuadbba etÂ al., 2020; Ceballos etÂ al., 2020). In Horizontal FL, data is split by entity (e.g. a person), and data entities owned by each party are complete and disjoint from other parties. In Vertical FL (vFL), a data entity is split into different attributes (e.g. features and labels of the same person), and each party might own the same data entity but different attributes. One typical example of vFL is a collaboration between general and specialized hospitals. They might hold the data for the same patient, but the general hospital owns generic information (i.e. features) of the patient while the specialized hospital owns the specific testing results (i.e. labels) of the same patient. Therefore they can use vFL to jointly train a model that predicts a specific disease examined by the specialized hospital from the features provided by the general hospital.

One critical stage in vFL is identifying the same entities shared by all parties which we define as intersection. In standard vFL, this is achieved by Private Set Intersection (PSI) protocols Â (Kolesnikov etÂ al., 2016; Pinkas etÂ al., 2018). Before the training starts, all parties need to run PSI protocols to identify the intersection to align sample IDs. The sample ID needs to be certain universally identifiable information that can be used to identify entities across organizations. The common option is some personal identifiable information (e.g. phone and email). After all parties obtain the sample IDs of the intersection, they can jointly train a model on the intersection.

However, the PSI protocol would make the sample IDs of the intersection visible to all parties. As a result, every party would know that the entities in the intersection also exist in the other partiesâ€™ data, and we define this information as intersection membership. In many real-world privacy-sensitive organizations, membership information is highly sensitive and cannot be shared with the other parties. For example, hospitals cannot reveal which patient is a member and banks cannot disclose which client owns an account. In practice, this leakage significantly limits the applicability of vFL since vFL participants are privacy-sensitive but the membership leakage conflicts with the privacy-preserving intention of using vFL.

Only a few of existing work attempts to address the intersection membership leakage problem in vFL. Existing work in protecting the privacy of vFL mostly focuses on preventing data leakageÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2020; Wu etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2021) rather than membership leakage. The closest work isÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2020), which adapts PSI to achieve the asymmetrical ID alignment in an asymmetrical vFL. However, their protocol still exposes the intersection membership to one party and cannot protect all parties. To the best of our knowledge, our work is the first attempt to protect intersection membership information for all parties.

In this paper, we design a novel vFL framework to address the problem of intersection membership leakage. Our framework can train models without revealing the membership information while maintaining the model utility. To achieve our goal, we need to overcome two main technical challenges: 1) How to securely align training samples without the knowledge of their intersection? 2) How to design an effective learning mechanism based on the secured alignments to protect privacy while retaining the model utility?

To answer the questions, we propose a novel Private Set Union (PSU) protocol that does not reveal sample IDs of the intersection, and therefore no membership information about the intersection would be leaked. Instead, it identifies the union of the training instances and uses it as the training data in our framework. In addition, we design several strategies to generate synthetic features and labels for samples that belong to the union but not the intersection. We summarize our contributions as follows:

  • â€¢

    We propose the first vFL framework that protects the membership information of all parties.

  • â€¢

    We design a novel Private Set Union protocol that can securely align data entities without revealing membership information of the intersection.

  • â€¢

    We design several synthetic data generation strategies for samples which belong to the union but not the intersection. Through extensive experiments, we show our strategies are both secure and utility-preserving.

2.2 Overview of FLORIST

We propose Federated Learning withOut Revealing InterSecTions, or FLORIST, to remove the need of revealing the intersection membership in vFL. Specifically, we perform mini-batch SGD training on the union of the training samples. As shown in FigureÂ 1, our framework consists of two modules: Private Set Union (PSU) for ID alignment and synthetic data generation. PSU is designed to align data samples securely without exposing sample IDs of the intersection.PSU outputs a set of universal IDs with which both parties schedule the mini-batch training. First, in PSU, no information on the intersection set, except for the size of the intersection, is revealed. Second, when a party (either passive or active) is given a training sample (iâ€‹di,xi,yi)ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–({id}_{i},{x}_{i},{y}_{i}) in a mini-batch generated from the union, it is possible that iâ€‹diğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–id_{i} is not in its dataset. Therefore the party needs to generate synthetic data to ensure a valid training procedure. For example, as shown in Figure 1, the passive party provides synthetic features for [p4]delimited-[]subscriptğ‘4[p_{4}], and the active party provides synthetic labels for [p2]delimited-[]subscriptğ‘2[p_{2}] and [p3]delimited-[]subscriptğ‘3[p_{3}], where [.][.] represents the encrypted ID space.

Threat Model.

We assume malicious parties are honest-but-curious, i.e. ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} and ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} faithfully run the vFL protocol, but they may infer important information including raw sample data and intersection membership from the exchanged information. In particular, we consider two privacy leakage scenarios: 1) for iâ€‹dâˆˆâ„ağ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}, ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} finds out if iâ€‹dâˆˆâ„aâˆ©â„pğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p} by checking yiâ€‹dsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘‘y_{id} and the embedding forwarded by ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p}, and 2) for iâ€‹dâˆˆâ„pğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘id\in\mathcal{I}_{p}, ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} finds out if iâ€‹dâˆˆâ„aâˆ©â„pğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘id\in\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p} by checking xiâ€‹dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‘x_{id} and the gradient sent back by ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a}.

2.3 Private Set Union for ID-alignment

We first introduce our PSU protocol for secured entity alignment. On a high level, by running the PSU protocol, parties ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} and ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} jointly compute a bijection u:(â„aâˆªâ„p)â†”U:ğ‘¢subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘â†”ğ‘ˆu:(\mathcal{I}_{a}\cup\mathcal{I}_{p})\leftrightarrow U, where Uğ‘ˆU is a set of encrypted universal identifiers (UID) shared by both parties. Furthermore, the active party ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} knows uâ€‹(iâ€‹d)ğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘‘u(id) for all iâ€‹dâˆˆâ„ağ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘id\in\mathcal{I}_{a} and the passive party ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} knows uâ€‹(iâ€‹d)ğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘‘u(id) for all iâ€‹dâˆˆâ„pğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptâ„ğ‘id\in\mathcal{I}_{p}. Therefore the membership information that can be inferred from sample IDs aligned by PSI would not be leaked by PSU. Finally, under the decisional Diffieâ€“Hellman assumption, our PSU protocol leaks no information other than |â„a|,|â„p|,|â„aâˆ©â„p|subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,|\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p}| to an honest-but-curious malicious party.

The set Uğ‘ˆU is used to schedule mini-batch training in the following way: for each batch, both parties agree on a sequence u1,u2,â‹¯âˆˆUsubscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢2â‹¯ğ‘ˆu_{1},u_{2},\cdots\in U. For each uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}, both parties check whether uâˆ’1â€‹(ui)superscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u^{-1}(u_{i}) is contained in their own ID set, and if so, they feed the corresponding real data into the model; otherwise, they apply the data generation methods (detailed described in SectionÂ 2.4) to generate synthetic data to feed into the model.

Our PSU protocol is presented in Algorithm 1. It consists of two parallel independent parts: in the first part, both parties jointly compute the union of UID, but they do not know the mapping from the ID set to Uğ‘ˆU. We use two rounds of Diffieâ€“Hellman key exchange scheme so that ğ’«a,ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘subscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a},\mathcal{P}_{p} cannot identify if some sample ID is in the intersection. In the second part, ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} and ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} compute the mapping from â„a,â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{a},\mathcal{I}_{p} to Uğ‘ˆU respectively.

We present the security guarantee of our PSU protocol. The security assumption is based on the hardness of the Decisional Diffieâ€“Hellman (DDH) problem. Let pğ‘p be a prime satisfying that q=pâˆ’12ğ‘ğ‘12q=\frac{p-1}{2} is also a prime. (pğ‘p is a so-called safe prime). 2.4 Synthetic Data Generation

Given a training sample (iâ€‹di,xi,yi)ğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–({id}_{i},{x}_{i},{y}_{i}) in a mini-batch generated from the union of all samples, it is possible that iâ€‹diğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–id_{i} is not in â„asubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{a} or â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{p}. In such cases, ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} or ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} need to generate synthetic data. We introduce strategies to generate synthetic labels for active party and synthetic features for passive party respectively. The proposed strategies are designed to prevent the malicious parties from distinguishing which data point is synthetic while maintaining the model performance.

Synthetic Labels Generation for Passive Party.

The gradient gğ‘”g sent to the passive party is a matrix in â„BÃ—dsuperscriptâ„ğµğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{B\times d} with each row belonging to a specific sample ID in the batch with size BğµB. Here the gradients as rows of the matrix are gradients of the loss with respect to intermediate computation results of different samples. Synthetic gradients should be provided for samples which are not in the sample ID space (â„asubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{a}) of the active party to protect privacy. There are two ways to generate synthetic gradients: 1) generate synthetic labels firstly and use the corresponding labels to compute training loss and then generate the corresponding gradients; 2) generate synthetic gradients directly without setting labels. We design several strategies such as k-nearest neighbors to generate synthetic gradients from actual gradients and empirically find these strategies insecure, i.e., the passive party can distinguish synthetic gradients from real ones. Therefore we focus on generating synthetic labels.

The synthetic label generation strategy is based on the following observation: the datasets in many real-world applications such as online advertising and healthcare are imbalanced. The negative samples significantly outnumber the positive ones. For example, Criteo222https://www.kaggle.com/c/criteo-display-ad-challenge/data and Avazu333https://www.kaggle.com/c/avazu-ctr-prediction/data are two real-world large-scale binary classification datasets, and both datasets are highly imbalanced: only 25%percent2525\% of the Criteo and 17%percent1717\% of the Avazu samples are positive. Hence, given a binary classification problem, itâ€™s reasonable to assign the missing labels as negative (00 as the label).

Synthetic Features Generation for Active Party.

For sample IDs not in â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{p}, the passive party generates synthetic raw features for them. A naive strategy is to generate random values as synthetic features. However, random values and real features have different distributions; the active party can utilize tools like clustering and outlier detection from robust statistics to decide which features are synthetic and then â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{p} is leaked to the active party. Empirically we demonstrated the effectiveness of using SVD-based outlier detection methodÂ Tran etÂ al. (2018) to distinguish random values from real features.

We present our method that best protects the privacy. We show that, theoretically, the best strategy for the ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} is to generate synthetic features according to the marginal distribution of real data. Let Dâ€‹(x,y)ğ·ğ‘¥ğ‘¦D(x,y) be the (unknown) ground truth distribution of the feature-label pairs whose IDs are not owned by ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p}, and qâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…q(\cdot) be the distribution of labels of those data. As ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} does not have access to labels, its generation strategy can be characterized by a distribution pâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…p(\cdot). That is, whenever the passive party needs to generate a synthetic feature, it samples from pğ‘p. Because features and labels are independent for synthetic data, the joint distribution is of the form Dâ€²â€‹(x,y)=pâ€‹(x)â‹…qâ€‹(y)superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â‹…ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¦D^{\prime}(x,y)=p(x)\cdot q(y). In order to have the best privacy, we want D,Dâ€²ğ·superscriptğ·â€²D,D^{\prime} to be as close as possible. The following theorem suggests that the marginal distribution is optimal in minimizing KL-divergence. The proof is included in AppendixÂ B.

Theorem 2 (folklore).

Let pğ‘p be a distribution over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} and qğ‘q be a distribution over ğ’´ğ’´\mathcal{Y}. Let Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} be a joint distribution over ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y} given by Dâ€²â€‹(x,y)=pâ€‹(x)â€‹qâ€‹(y)superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¦D^{\prime}(x,y)=p(x)q(y). Let pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*} be a distribution over ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} given by pâˆ—â€‹(x)=âˆ«yDâ€‹(x,y)â€‹ğ‘‘ysuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¦ğ·ğ‘¥ğ‘¦differential-dğ‘¦p^{*}(x)=\int_{y}D(x,y)dy. Then KL(D||Dâ€²)\text{KL}(D||D^{\prime}) is minimized when p=pâˆ—ğ‘superscriptğ‘p=p^{*}.

Nevertheless, ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} has no access to pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*} because ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} simply does not have these features. Here we make the assumption that the data distribution is the same across data corresponding to ID sets â„aâˆ©â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{a}\cap\mathcal{I}_{p}, â„aâˆ’â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{a}-\mathcal{I}_{p} and â„pâˆ’â„asubscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{p}-\mathcal{I}_{a}. Then ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} could think of its feature set ğ’³psubscriptğ’³ğ‘\mathcal{X}_{p} follows the distribution of pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*}.

As it is difficult to accurately estimate marginal distribution on input features (a high dimension distribution), we use the following sampling method to generate synthetic features: the passive party uses a random real sample to fill in the non-existing features. The raw features (including real and synthetic) will be fed to the same network and generate the intermediate embeddings at the cut layer.

Logits Calibration.

As our data generation scheme changes the data distribution, it can cause large adaptive calibration (ACE) errorÂ (Nixon etÂ al., 2019). ACE measures how well a modelâ€™s predicted probabilities of outcomes reflect true probabilities of those outcomes. We adapt a method named logits shiftÂ (Chapelle etÂ al., 2015) to handle the calibration error. On a high level, since both parties know how synthetic data is generated, they can estimate how the data distribution deviates from the underlying one, which allows them to modify the model to account for ACE. Empirically we demonstrated that this method can reduce the ACE significantly. Details of how to do the calibration via logits shift can be seen in the appendix.

3 Empirical Study

In this section, we experimentally evaluate the proposed framework. Since PSU is an alignment protocol and it is proved to be secure, the main goal of the empirical study is to demonstrate the effectiveness of the data generation strategies. We run three groups of simulations: 1) Simulations with Synthetic Labels Only. During training, partial labels of the active party are synthetic. We measure the performance of our proposed synthetic label generation with varying synthetic label ratio Î²ğ›½\beta. 2) Simulations with Synthetic Features Only. During training, partial features provided by the passive party are synthetic. We check the performance with varying synthetic feature ratio Î±ğ›¼\alpha. 3) Simulations with Both Synthetic Labels and Features. During training, partial data of both parties are synthetic. We check our performance with varying Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta.

Dataset and Model.

We use two real-world datasets: Criteo and Avazu. Criteo is a large-scale binary classification dataset with approximately 454545 million user click records in online advertising. Avazu contains approximately 404040 million entries (111111 days of clicks/not clicks of Avazu data). We defer the similar results on Avazu to AppendixÂ I and only report the results of Criteo in this section. We split each dataset randomly into two parts: with 90%percent9090\% for training and the rest for tests. We train a modified Wide&Deep model (Cheng etÂ al., 2016) where the passive party consists of embedding layers for input features and two layers of 128128128-unit ReLU activated multilayer perceptron (half deep part) and the active party consists of the last two layers of the deep part. In every iteration, the passive party sends a mini-batch of 8,19281928,192 examplesâ€™ 128128128-dimensional vectors to the active party and the active party sends the gradients of the loss w.r.t. these vectors back to the passive side.

Evaluation Metrics.

We measure the model utility by the AUC and ACE. A model with an ideal utility should have a high AUC and a low ACE. We also measure the security of the synthetic data generation stage since an honest-but-curious party could try to infer which data samples from the other party are synthetic or real. Therefore it might introduce new membership leakage. To this end, theoretically we can estimate the difference between the distribution Dğ·D of actual data and the distribution Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} of synthetic data. Yet these distributions are over high-dimensional data and it is intractable to compute the distance. Instead, we use spectral attack (Tran etÂ al., 2018), a 2-clustering outlier detection algorithm that can be used to predict if an embedding or gradient is real or synthetic. The AUC of its prediction, which we call it as attack AUC, measures how well the malicious parties could distinguish real data and synthetic data generated by our strategies. A closer to 0.50.50.5 attack AUC is considered to be more secure. More details on the spectral attack can be found in AppendixÂ C.

3.1 Simulations with Synthetic Labels Only

We conduct experiments to simulate the scenario that only the active party has to provide synthetic labels for unowned instances during training. The passive party owns all the sample IDs and hence it provides real features for all training instances. Based on the observation that both Criteo and Avazu datasets are highly imbalanced (only 25%percent2525\% of the samples in Criteo and 17%percent1717\% in Avazu are positive), our label-majority generates synthetic label yi~=0~subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–0\widetilde{y_{i}}=0, âˆ€iâ€‹diâˆ‰â„afor-allğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘\forall\ {id}_{i}\notin\mathcal{I}_{a}. We also test several other synthetic label generation strategies for the active party: âˆ€iâ€‹diâˆ‰â„afor-allğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘\forall\ {id}_{i}\notin\mathcal{I}_{a}, 1) label-minority sets yi~=1~subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–1\widetilde{y_{i}}=1; 2) label-random-pos randomly samples a label for yi~~subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\widetilde{y_{i}}, based on the positive instance ratio of ğ’Ÿasubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘\mathcal{D}_{a}; 3) label-random-pred randomly samples a label for yi~~subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\widetilde{y_{i}}, based on the predicted positive probability for iâ€‹diğ‘–subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–{id}_{i}; 4) label-neighbors determines yi~~subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\widetilde{y_{i}}, based on a k-nearest-neighbors strategy (with k=3ğ‘˜3k=3 and cosine similarity to measure the similarity between cut layer embeddings).

We test different synthetic label ratio Î²ğ›½\beta and report performance from different generation strategies. We compare the above generation strategies with two baselines. 1) baseline-partial: Given a Î²ğ›½\beta, it only uses the rest (1âˆ’Î²)1ğ›½(1-\beta) real labels to train the model; 2) baseline-full: it uses the whole real dataset to train the model, which can be viewed as an upper-bound for all competitors.

For each Î²ğ›½\beta, every experiment uses the same fixed random seed to select unowned instances of the passive party. All strategies have the same real data as used in baseline-partial to train the model. The corresponding results of AUC and ACE are shown in Figure Â 2 (a) and (d) respectively. We can observe that using less data decreases the model performance. Unsurprisingly, the gap between baseline-partial and baseline-full gradually enlarges with increasing Î²ğ›½\beta. For example, when Î²=95%ğ›½percent95\beta=95\%, baseline-partial drops about 3.8%percent3.83.8\% in comparing with baseline-full.

As shown in Figure 2 (a), label-majority can achieve comparable AUC with baseline-partial. However, label-majority changes the data distribution and causes high ACE. As shown in Figure 2 (d), label-majority has a larger ACE than baselines, and therefore it is necessary to calibrate the predicted logits for label-majority. Depending on when to have the calibration, we provide two variants of label-majority: label-majority-te and label-majority-tr. For label-majority-te, we leave the training logits unchanged and perform the calibration in the testing. For label-majority-tr, we only calibrates the predicted logits in the training. More details are included in Appendix E.

As shown in Figure 2 (d), we find both options reduce the ACE significantly and achieve similar ACE with baselines. Regarding the AUC, label-majority-tr only drops about 0.67%percent0.670.67\% and 0.33%percent0.330.33\% in comparing with baseline-partial when Î²ğ›½\beta is 95%percent9595\% and 50%percent5050\% respectively. Meanwhile, as shown in Table 1, the attack AUC of label-majority and its variants are all around 0.570.570.57. Though label-random-pred has the best privacy among all competitors (detailed analysis can be seen in Appendix H), its utility is worse than label-majority. Therefore our proposed label-majority is highly effective in both protecting privacy and maintaining model utility.

3.3 Simulations with Both Synthetic Labels and Features

We conduct experiments with a more realistic scenario: both parties provide synthetic data. We vary Î²ğ›½\beta in the passive party and Î±ğ›¼\alpha in the active party and compare our proposed approach FLORIST-vanilla and FLORIST with baselines (baseline-full and baseline-partial). Both FLORIST-vanilla and FLORIST leverage label-majority to generate synthetic labels and fea-sampling to generate synthetic features. The difference is that FLORIST leverages logits calibration to reduce ACE caused by synthetic features and labels, while FLORIST-vanilla only deals with calibration with label-majority-te. Both parties may add dummy sample IDs to perturb the union of training samples. Hence, training instances with synthetic label and feature simultaneously are allowed in our experiments.

4 Related Work

Vertical Federated Learning.

Vertical Federated LearningÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Abuadbba etÂ al., 2020; Ceballos etÂ al., 2020) considers the scenario where multiple parties own different attributes of the same entities. Existing vFL protocolsÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Chen etÂ al., 2020; Wu etÂ al., 2020) are all based on identifying and then training the model on the intersection. Therefore it would unavoidably leak the intersection membership. Our work is also closely related to Split Neural Network (SplitNN)Â (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2018; Gupta and Raskar, 2018; Abuadbba etÂ al., 2020; Ceballos etÂ al., 2020), which is another framework that can be used in vFL scenario.

Private Set Union.

Despite extensive study on PSIÂ (DeÂ Cristofaro and Tsudik, 2010; DeÂ Cristofaro etÂ al., 2010; Huang etÂ al., 2012; Hazay and Venkitasubramaniam, 2017; Pinkas etÂ al., 2019), little is known on PSU until the work of Kissner and SongÂ (Kissner and Song, 2005). Existing work on PSU employs advanced techniques in multi-party computation including additive homomorphic encryptionÂ (Kissner and Song, 2005; Frikken, 2007; Davidson and Cid, 2017), Bloom filterÂ (Davidson and Cid, 2017), garbling circuitsÂ (Blanton and Aguiar, 2016), and oblivious transferÂ (Blanton and Aguiar, 2016; Kolesnikov etÂ al., 2019). Different from prior work, we compute the union of hash function of the ID sets so that the raw ID information is not used in the training procedure. Our PSU protocol is based on the Diffieâ€“Hellman key exchange schemeÂ (Diffie and Hellman, 1976), and is inspired by the work of Buddhavarapu et.al. (Buddhavarapu etÂ al., 2020). Compared to (Buddhavarapu etÂ al., 2020), our protocol is conceptually cleaner because we decouple the union computation from identifying the hash mapping.

5 Conclusion

We propose a novel vFL framework that addresses the intersection membership leakage problem which currently prevents many privacy-sensitive organizations from adopting vFL. Our framework uses PSU to generate a union of all samples, which does not reveal intersection membership information to all parties. In addition, synthetic data generation strategies are proposed to handle samples belong to the union but not the intersection. We experimentally show that our method can protect the intersection membership without a significant drop in model performance.

Limitations.

We point out two limitations in our framework. First, compared to the PSI approach, our PSU increases the training sample size from the intersection size (|â„pâˆ©â„a|subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘|\mathcal{I}_{p}\cap\mathcal{I}_{a}|) to the union size (|â„pâˆªâ„a|subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘|\mathcal{I}_{p}\cup\mathcal{I}_{a}|). Therefore, when the union is significantly larger than the intersection, our method would incur a non-negligible training cost compared to PSI. In practice, the larger party can choose to downsample its data to reduce training overhead. In addition, before the training starts, parties can estimate the additional training cost by measuring the size difference between intersection and union, and then choose between our framework and traditional PSI. Second, synthetic label generation label-majority is specifically designed for unbalanced binary classification tasks such as online advertising and healthcare applications. We leave a more general strategy (other than label-random-pred) for balanced binary classification and multi-classification problems as future work.

Appendix A Security Analysis of Private Set Union

We first introduce some notations in multi-party computation adapted fromÂ Lindell [2017]. The view of a party Pğ‘ƒP (either ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} or ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p}), consists of the input of Pğ‘ƒP (either â„asubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{a} or â„psubscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}_{p}), the internal randomness used by Pğ‘ƒP, and all the messages Pğ‘ƒP receives during the MPC procedure. Let n=maxâ¡{|â„a|,|â„p|,âŒˆlogâ¡pâŒ‰}ğ‘›subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘n=\max\{|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,\lceil\log p\rceil\} be the security parameter, where pğ‘p is the prime number used in Algorithm 1. A simulator Sğ‘†S for Pğ‘ƒP is a probabilistic algorithm that takes the input of Pğ‘ƒP and |â„a|,|â„p|,|â„aâˆªâ„p|subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘|\mathcal{I}_{a}|,|\mathcal{I}_{p}|,|\mathcal{I}_{a}\cup\mathcal{I}_{p}| as input, runs in time polynomial in nğ‘›n, and outputs a transcript that is indistinguishable to the view of Pğ‘ƒP for any polynomial time algorithm.

The idea behind simulation based proof is that for honest-but-curious malicious party, all the information it could inspect is from its view. Therefore, if the view of malicious party is indistinguishable to the output of the simulator, then any polynomial time malicious party cannot infer more information other than the input of the simulator.

Now we can state our formal result on the security of our PSU protocol. We first present a simulator Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a} against ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a}, which is described in AlgorithmÂ 2. The security guarantee is shown in Theorem 3

Theorem 3.

Assume that the Decisional Diffieâ€“Hellman problem is hard for Qâ€‹Râ€‹(â„¤pâˆ—)ğ‘„ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptâ„¤ğ‘QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}). Then the distribution of the view of ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} by running Algorithm 1 is indistinguishable to the output of Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a} for any distinguisher that runs in time polynomial in nğ‘›n.

Proof.

The proof follows fromÂ Buddhavarapu etÂ al. [2020] and adapts a hybrid argument. Notice that the output of Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a} is essentially replacing the messages from ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} with proper random elements from â„¤qsubscriptâ„¤ğ‘\mathbb{Z}_{q}. Therefore we can build a sequence of hybrid views, where we start with the view of ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} by really executing Algorithm 1, and we end with the view that is the output of Sasubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{a}. Furthermore, neighboring hybrid views only differ at one place. We are going to argue that distinguishing neighboring views can be reduced to the DDH problem, hence proves the security.

Let us see a concrete example. Assume that for two neighboring views visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i}, vi+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–1v_{i+1}, the only difference is that in Line (2), for one single xâˆˆâ„aâˆ’â„pğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptâ„ğ‘x\in\mathcal{I}_{a}-\mathcal{I}_{p}, visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i} uses xs1â€‹t1superscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘¡1x^{s_{1}t_{1}}, while vi+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–1v_{i+1} uses gs1superscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘ 1g^{s_{1}} for some gâˆˆGğ‘”ğºg\in G. We now construct a reduction from DDH to distinguish these two views. We next present a simulator Spsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘S_{p} against ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} in Algorithm 3. Since Algorithm 1 is highly symmetric, the corresponding security proof is quite similar and is hence omitted. The security guarantee is summarized in the following theorem:

Theorem 4.

Assume that the Decisional Diffieâ€“Hellman problem is hard for Qâ€‹Râ€‹(â„¤pâˆ—)ğ‘„ğ‘…superscriptsubscriptâ„¤ğ‘QR(\mathbb{Z}_{p}^{*}). Appendix C Spectral Attack

In this section we present the theoretical background of the spectral attack. Spectral attack is a singular value decomposition (SVD) based outlier detection method introduced by Tran, Li and MadryÂ Tran etÂ al. [2018]. In particular, they show that

Lemma 1 (Lemma 3.1, Definition 3.1 in Tran etÂ al. [2018]).

Fix 0<Ïµ<120italic-Ïµ120<\epsilon<\frac{1}{2}. Let Dğ·D, Wğ‘ŠW be two distributions over â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} with mean Î¼D,Î¼Wsubscriptğœ‡ğ·subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Š\mu_{D},\mu_{W} and covariance matrices Î£D,Î£WsubscriptÎ£ğ·subscriptÎ£ğ‘Š\Sigma_{D},\Sigma_{W}. Let Fğ¹F be a mixture distribution given by F=(1âˆ’Ïµ)â€‹D+Ïµâ€‹Wğ¹1italic-Ïµğ·italic-Ïµğ‘ŠF=(1-\epsilon)D+\epsilon W. If â€–Î¼Dâˆ’Î¼Wâ€–22â‰¥6â€‹Ïƒ2Ïµsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğœ‡ğ·subscriptğœ‡ğ‘Š226superscriptğœ2italic-Ïµ\|\mu_{D}-\mu_{W}\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{6\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon}, then the following statement holds: let Î¼Fsubscriptğœ‡ğ¹\mu_{F} be the mean of Fğ¹F and vğ‘£v be the top singular vector of the covariance matrix of Fğ¹F, then there exists tğ‘¡t>0 so that

PrXâˆ¼Dâ¡[|âŸ¨Xâˆ’Î¼F,vâŸ©|>t]<subscriptPrsimilar-toğ‘‹ğ·ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ¹ğ‘£ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\Pr_{X\sim D}[|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle|>t]< Ïµ,italic-Ïµ\displaystyle~{}\epsilon,
PrXâˆ¼Wâ¡[|âŸ¨Xâˆ’Î¼F,vâŸ©|<t]<subscriptPrsimilar-toğ‘‹ğ‘Šğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ¹ğ‘£ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\Pr_{X\sim W}[|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle|<t]< Ïµ.italic-Ïµ\displaystyle~{}\epsilon.

This gives us one attack method to distinguish the distribution Dğ·D of real data between the distribution Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} of synthetic data. Lemma 1 suggests that if the mean of Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} are far away from each other, then we can use |âŸ¨Xâˆ’Î¼F,vâŸ©|ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ¹ğ‘£|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle| as the indicator to distinguish Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}.

In experiments, for each mini-batch, we compute the attack AUC for the passive party ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} when the synthetic label ratio Î²>0ğ›½0\beta>0 and for the active party ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a} when the synthetic feature ratio Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. For ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p}, we consider the distribution over the gradients gğ‘”g sent back by ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a}. For ğ’«asubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{a}, we consider the joint distribution over the intermediate embeddings fğ‘“f sent from ğ’«psubscriptğ’«ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{p} and the labels yğ‘¦y. We estimate Î¼Fsubscriptğœ‡ğ¹\mu_{F} and vğ‘£v by computing the empirical mean and covariance matrix with data in the mini-batch. Then we are able to compute the score |âŸ¨Xâˆ’Î¼F,vâŸ©|ğ‘‹subscriptğœ‡ğ¹ğ‘£|\langle X-\mu_{F},v\rangle| for each sample in the batch. Finally, we compute the attack AUC as how these scores predict if each sample is synthetic or not.

Appendix D Federated Model Training and Serving

After we leverage PSU to align the dataset and provide synthetic data using strategies as described in previous subsection, we then introduce how to do the federated model training and serving. In this paper we focus on two parties learning a model for a binary classification problem over the domain ğ’³Ã—{0,1}ğ’³01\mathcal{X}\times\left\{0,1\right\}. Here the passive and active parties want to learn a composition model hâˆ˜fâ„ğ‘“h\circ f jointly, where the raw features Xğ‘‹X and f:ğ’³â†’â„d:ğ‘“â†’ğ’³superscriptâ„ğ‘‘f:\mathcal{X}\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{d} are stored on the passive party side while the labels yğ‘¦y and h:â„dâ†’â„:â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„h:\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\to\operatorname{\mathbb{R}} is on the active party side. Let â„“=hâ€‹(fâ€‹(X))â„“â„ğ‘“ğ‘‹\ell=h(f(X)) be the logit of the positive class where the positive classâ€™s predicted probability is given by the sigmoid function. The loss of the model is given by the cross entropy.

To train the model using gradient descent, the passive party computes fâ€‹(X)ğ‘“ğ‘‹f(X) with both synthetic and real raw features Xğ‘‹X and sends it to the active party who will then complete the rest of computation (Forward in Table 4).555 For the simplifying of the notation and derivation, we add no additional features in the active party to compute the logit. The data generation strategies can be adapted for other complicated settings. Then the active party starts the gradient computation process by first computing the gradient of the loss with respect to the logit dâ€‹Ldâ€‹â„“=(pÂ¯1âˆ’y)ğ‘‘ğ¿ğ‘‘â„“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘1ğ‘¦\frac{dL}{d\ell}=(\overline{p}_{1}-y). Here yğ‘¦y contains both synthetic and real labels. Using the chain rule, the active party can then compute the gradient of Lğ¿L with respect to hâ„hâ€™s parameters through â„“â„“\ell. In order to allow the passive party to learn fğ‘“f, the active party also computes the gradient of Lğ¿L with respect to the input of the function hâ„h. We denote this gradient by gğ‘”g (equality by chain rule). After receiving gğ‘”g sent from the active party, the passive party can compute the gradient of Lğ¿L w.r.t. fğ‘“fâ€™s parameters (Backward in Table 4).

When BğµB examples are forwarded as a batch, the communicated features fâ€‹(X)ğ‘“ğ‘‹f(X) and gradients gğ‘”g will both be matrices of shape â„BÃ—dsuperscriptâ„ğµğ‘‘\operatorname{\mathbb{R}}^{B\times d} with each row belonging to a specific example in the batch. It is important to note that here the gradients as rows of the matrix are gradients of the loss with respect to different examplesâ€™ intermediate computation results but not the model parameters; therefore, no averaging over or shuffling of the rows of the matrix can be done prior to communication for the sake of correct gradient computation of fğ‘“fâ€™s parameters on the passive party side.

For model inference, suppose that the passive party would like to know the prediction of instance iğ‘–i from the active party. The passive party only feeds iğ‘–iâ€™s raw feature xğ‘¥x and computes fâ€‹(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x). If no additional features are added in the active party to compute the logit, then the active party directly computes pi=1/(1+expâ¡(âˆ’hâ€‹(fâ€‹(x))))subscriptğ‘ğ‘–11â„ğ‘“ğ‘¥p_{i}=1/(1+\exp(-h(f(x)))) and sends pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i} to the passive party without knowing any ID information of iğ‘–i. Otherwise if additional features are needed for active party, the passive party can hide instance iğ‘–i in a batch which both parties have agreements on. Then the serving process will be the as same as the forward process during the training phase. After receiving a batch of predictions from the active party, the passive party can select the corresponding prediction for iğ‘–i.

Appendix H Synthetic Label Generation: label-random-pred

In this section we show the theoretical analysis of label-random-pred. It is inspired by the so-called â€œlog-derivative trickâ€, and the goal is to mitigate the effect of synthetic labels on the model updates. Notice that in binary classification problems, âˆ€xâˆˆğ’³for-allğ‘¥ğ’³\forall x\in\mathcal{X}, for any prediction model pğ‘p, we always have âˆ‘yi=01pâ€‹(yi|x)=1superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–01ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘¥1\sum_{y_{i}=0}^{1}p(y_{i}|x)=1. Let Wğ‘ŠW be the weight on the cut layer, and (x1,y1),(x2,y2),â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¦1subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘¦2â‹¯(x_{1},y_{1}),(x_{2},y_{2}),\cdots be the training samples in a mini-batch. âˆ‘yi=01qxiâ€‹(yi)â€‹âˆ‚logâ¡pâ€‹(yi|xi)âˆ‚W=0.superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–01subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘Š0\displaystyle\sum_{y_{i}=0}^{1}q_{x_{i}}(y_{i})\frac{\partial\log p(y_{i}|x_{i})}{\partial W}=0.

Notice that âˆ‘yi=01qxiâ€‹(yi)â€‹logâ¡pâ€‹(yi|xi)superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–01subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\sum_{y_{i}=0}^{1}q_{x_{i}}(y_{i})\log p(y_{i}|x_{i}) can be interpreted as the expectation of the cross-entropy loss if we generate synthetic labels according to qxisubscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–q_{x_{i}}. This explains the intuition of label-random-pred: we simply generate the synthetic label yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i} according to the model prediction pâ€‹(yi|xi)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–p(y_{i}|x_{i}). If qğ‘q and Wğ‘ŠW are independent, then the expected gradient with respect to the cross-entropy loss is exactly 00, namely the synthetic labels do not affect model updates on average.

label-random-pred performs better than label-minority, label-neighbors, and label-random-pos. However, the variance could be large when we only sample once to generate the label. To reduce the variance, we can increase the sample times and average the gradients generated from each sampled label. As a result, we can have better performance at the cost of worse privacy, because the gradients corresponding to synthetic labels tend to be close to 0. Such a trade-off can be observed in TableÂ 5. This experiment is conducted on the Avazu dataset with 2 epochs of training.

One advantage of label-random-pred is that it can not only be applied to both balanced and unbalanced binary classification problems but also multi-classification problems.

Appendix I Experimental Results on the Avazu Dataset

In this section, we report the experiment result on Avazu dataset. Avazu is a dataset of click-through data with approximately 40 million entries (11 days of clicks/not clicks of Avazu data). Overall, the trends of all evaluation metrics are very similar to those in the experiments on Cretio reported in SectionÂ 3.

I.1 Simulations with Synthetic Labels Only

The experiment results on Avazu dataset of AUC and ACE are shown in FigureÂ 3 (a) and (d) respectively. The attack AUC can be found in Table 6. We can see that label-majority can achieve similar AUC compared to baseline-partial, while maintaining a relatively low attack AUC (about 0.55). Furthermore, by applying logits shift, ACE can be lowered to the scale of baseline-partial. These experiment results reaffirm the validity of using label-majority with logits shift as the generation strategy for the active party.

I.2 Simulations with Synthetic Features Only

The experiment results on Avazu dataset of AUC and ACE are shown in FigureÂ 3 (b) and (e) respectively. The attack AUC can be found in Table 7. Again we find that fea-Gaussian and fea-random have comparable AUC with baseline-partial. However their attack AUC is very close to 111, meaning that they are not suitable for privacy-sensitive vFL. On the other hand, fea-sampling has a reasonable attack AUC, and the drop on AUC is moderate compared to baseline-partial. For instance, the AUC drops about 6.7%percent6.76.7\% and 0.88%percent0.880.88\% compared with baseline-partial when Î±=0.95ğ›¼0.95\alpha=0.95 and Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5 respectively. We also observe that logits shift can significantly lower the ACE.

I.3 Simulations with Both Synthetic Labels and Features

As in SectionÂ 3, here we report our experimental results with Î±=Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha=\beta. The experiment results of AUC and ACE are shown in FigureÂ 3 (c) and (f) respectively. We find that by applying logits shift, FLORIST greatly reduces ACE compared to FLORIST-vanilla. We also report the AUC drop for FLORIST compared to baseline-partial. The drop is barely minimal in scenarios close to real application (like Î±=Î²=0.5ğ›¼ğ›½0.5\alpha=\beta=0.5), and is still affordable even when Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\beta is as large as 0.950.950.95.

Appendix J Data Setup and Experimental Details

We first describe how we first preprocess each of the datasets. We then describe the model architecture used for each dataset. Finally, we describe what are the training hyperparameters used for each dataset/model combination and the total amount of compute required for the experiments.

Dataset preprocessing

[Criteo]

Every record of Criteo has 272727 categorical input features and 141414 real-valued input features. We first replace all the NA values in categorical features with a single new category (which we represent using the empty string) and all the NA values in real-valued features by 00. For each categorical feature, we convert each of its possible value uniquely to an integer between 00 (inclusive) and the total number of unique categories (exclusive). For each real-valued feature, we linearly normalize it into [0,1]01[0,1]. We then randomly sample 10%percent1010\% of the entire Criteo publicly provided training set as our entire dataset (for faster training to generate privacy-utility trade-off comparision) and further make the subsampled dataset into a 90%-10% train-test split.

[Avazu]

Unlike Criteo, each record in Avazu only has categorical input features. We similarly replace all NA value with a single new category (the empty string), and for each categorical feature, we convert each of its possible value uniquely to an integer between 00 (inclusive) and the total number of unique categories (exclusive). We use all the records in provided in Avazu and randomly split it into 90% for training and 10% for test.

Model architecture details

[Criteo]

We modified a popular deep learning model architecture WDL Cheng etÂ al. [2016] for online advertising. We first process the categorical features in a given record by applying an embedding lookup for every categorical featureâ€™s value. We use an embedding dimension of 4 for the deep part. After the lookup, the deep embeddings are then concatenated with the continuous features to form the raw input vectors for the deep part. The deep part processes the raw features using 4 ReLU-activated 128-unit MLP layers before producing a final logic value. The cut layer is after the output of the 2rd ReLU layer on the deep part.

Model training details

To ensure smooth optimization and sufficient training loss minimization, we use a slightly smaller learning rate than normal.

[Criteo]

We use the Adam optimizer with with a batch size of 8,192 and a learning rate of 1â€‹e1ğ‘’1eâˆ’44-4 throughout the entire training of 3 epochs (approximately 15k stochastic gradient updates).

[Avazu]

We use the Adam optimizer with a batch size of 8,192 and a learning rate of 1â€‹e1ğ‘’1eâˆ’44-4 throughout the entire training of 3 epochs (approximately 15k stochastic gradient updates).

We conduct our experiments over 8 Nvidia Tesla V100 GPU card. Each epoch of run of Avazu takes about 10 hours to finish on a single GPU card occupying 4GB of GPU RAM. Each epoch run of Criteo takes about 11 hours to finish on a single GPU card using 4 GB of GPU RAM.
